channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2021 The New York Times Company

item.title: Afghanistan Updates: Rockets Launched at Kabul Airport After U.S. Strikes
item.description: There were no casualties after the airport was defended by a counter-rocket system. On Sunday, a U.S. military drone blew up a vehicle full of explosives in Kabul.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: Taliban fighters at Kabul’s international airport on Saturday.

item.title: Colombia’s Troubles Put a President’s Legacy on the Line
item.description: In an interview, Iván Duque defended his performance amid the pandemic and social strife, which could prompt a leftward shift in elections next year.
item.dc:creator: Carlos Tejada and Julie Turkewitz
item.media:credit: Jean Chung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Iván Duque, the president of Colombia.

item.title: For France, American Vines Still Mean Sour Grapes
item.description: French authorities have tried to outlaw hardy American hybrids for 87 years. But climate change and the natural wine movement are giving renegade winemakers a lift.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi
item.media:credit: Andrea Mantovani for The New York Times
item.media:description: A tasting of forbidden wines at Hervé Garnier’s “Memory of the Vine” association in the village of Beaumont. Mr. Garnier, standing third from right, is one of the last stragglers in a long-running struggle against the French wine establishment and its allies in Paris.

item.title: ‘What Will Happen to Me?’ An Uncertain Future Awaits Afghans Who Fled
item.description: Tens of thousands clambered onto evacuation planes bound for Qatar. Many are now in limbo in overflowing processing centers, fearful of what comes next.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum and Najim Rahim
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: In this photograph released by the U.S. Central Command, American soldiers prepared to let evacuees on a plane at an air base in Qatar. Military regulations prevented independent news photography at the base.

item.title: As the Taliban Tighten Their Grip, Fears of Retribution Grow
item.description: Taliban leaders have promised amnesty to Afghan officials and soldiers, but there are increasing reports of detentions, disappearances and even executions.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: Taliban fighters outside the United States Embassy in Kabul, Afghanistan, last week. As the Americans withdraw their forces, many Afghans fear reprisal attacks from the Taliban.

item.title: What We Know About the 13 US Service Members Killed in Kabul
item.description: They had an average age of just over 22 and came from towns across the country.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Coronavirus in UK: Britons, Unfazed by High Covid Rates, Weigh Their ‘Price of Freedom’
item.description: Britain is reporting more than 30,000 new coronavirus cases a day, but the public seems to have moved on. Experts say this could be a glimpse into the future for other countries.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Concertgoers on Friday at the Reading Music Festival in Reading, England. “We don’t seem to care that we have these really high infection rates,” said Tim Spector, a professor of genetic epidemiology at King’s College London.

item.title: Myanmar’s Monks, Leaders of Past Protests, Are Divided Over the Coup
item.description: Some senior members of the Buddhist clergy have given their blessing to the generals in power. But hundreds of lower-ranking monks have been jailed for protesting.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Beech
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: Monks in Mandalay, Myanmar, protesting in February against the army’s takeover. “C.R.P.H.” refers to opposition politicians whom the military had prevented from taking office.

item.title: Giant Puppet of Syrian Refugee Angers Some on Walk Through Greece
item.description: “Little Amal” is on a 5,000-mile journey from Turkey to Britain to highlight the plight of Syrian refugees. But in Greece, some have objected to her presence, saying it could encourage more migrants.
item.dc:creator: Niki Kitsantonis and Alex Marshall
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.media:description: “Little Amal” last month in Gaziantep, Turkey, at the start of her 5,000-mile journey. She “walks” with the help of a team of puppeteers.

item.title: Is Vaccine Immunity Waning?
item.description: It may not really be waning much — which means universal booster shots may do little good.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Saul Martinez for The New York Times
item.media:description: A mobile vaccine clinic in West Palm Beach, Fla., this month.

item.title: North Korea Restarted Plutonium-Producing Reactor, U.N. Agency Warns
item.description: ​The activities at the sprawling nuclear complex in Yongbyon suggest that the country is once again ramping up its nuclear weapons program.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:credit: Satellite image Maxar Technologies, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A satellite image from March showing a steam plant near North Korea’s main atomic complex in Yongbyon.

item.title: Can Afghanistan’s Leading Broadcaster Survive the Taliban?
item.description: Tolo came to prominence with hard-hitting news, raucous reality shows and lurid Turkish soap operas. Now there are ominous signs that a violent media clampdown is underway.
item.dc:creator: Dan Bilefsky
item.media:description: A news program on Tolo, Afghanistan’s largest and most popular broadcaster, in Kabul in 2018.

item.title: Exile or Jail: The Grim Choice Facing Russian Opposition Leaders
item.description: Experts say the current exodus of journalists and dissidents is the biggest wave of political emigration in the country’s post-Soviet history.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: The Russian opposition activists Aleksei A. Navalny, Lyubov Sobol and Ivan Zhdanov taking part in a rally last year in Moscow.

item.title: A New Breed of Crisis: War and Warming Collide in Afghanistan
item.description: Unrest and climate change are creating an agonizing feedback loop that punishes some of the world’s most vulnerable people.
item.dc:creator: Somini Sengupta
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: Anti-Taliban figthers near Mazar-i-Sharif in July. “The war has exacerbated climate change impacts,” said Noor Ahmad Akhundzadah, a professor at Kabul University.

item.title: U.S. Shoots Down Rockets Aimed at Kabul Airport
item.description: The attacks came with just two days remaining before President Biden’s deadline to complete the withdrawal, capping 20 years of war in Afghanistan.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt and Dan Bilefsky
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:description: Taliban fighters investigate a burned-out car after multiple rockets were fired in Kabul, Afghanistan, on Monday.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: A U.S. drone strike in Kabul.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: Internally displaced Afghans living in a camp set up in a park in Kabul.

item.title: U.S. Strikes Explosive-Laden Vehicle in Kabul
item.description: The drone strike came after a warning from President Biden that another terrorist attack at the Afghan capital’s airport was “highly likely.”
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper and Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:description: A vehicle that was filled with explosives was damaged after a U.S. drone strike in Kabul, Afghanistan, on Sunday.

item.title: U.S. Conducts Drone Strike in Kabul and Winds Down Airlift as Deadline Nears
item.description: The strike eliminated what U.S. officials called an imminent terrorist threat. With the military evacuation of Afghans over, the United States and others say they will still get people out.
item.dc:creator: David Zucchino
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:description: Damage from what was reportedly a U.S. drone strike on a vehicle carrying explosives at a house in Kabul on Sunday.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: Drone strikes in Afghanistan.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: Members of the Badri 313 Battalion, tasked with securing the airport in Kabul, Afghanistan, on Saturday.

item.title: The Latest News on Tropical Storm Nora
item.description: The storm, which was downgraded from a hurricane, battered western Mexico with rain and was also blamed for at least two injuries in Jalisco State.
item.dc:creator: Alyssa Lukpat
item.media:description: Floodwaters from Hurricane Nora undermined roads and damaged buildings in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico.

item.title: American University of Kabul Students Trying to Flee Were Sent Home
item.description: After seven hours of waiting for clearance to enter the airport gates, the group met a dead end: Evacuations were permanently called off.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi

item.title: E.U. Set to Propose Travel Restrictions on U.S. Visitors
item.description: Three officials from the bloc said that starting Monday, the European Council would advise its member states to ban nonessential travel from the United States.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier and Steven Erlanger
item.media:description: Passengers from countries listed as Covid-19 red zones registering for coronavirus tests upon their arrival at Paris Charles de Gaulle Airport, in April.

item.title: US Diplomats Unlikely to Stay in Afghanistan After Troops Leave
item.description: The U.S. mission to Afghanistan will likely open in a country elsewhere in the region.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: The exterior of the U.S. Embassy in Kabul, seen late on Aug. 15, the day the Taliban took control of the city.

item.title: Houses of worship struggle with fear of Delta’s rise within their congregations.
item.description: The variant’s spread came just as churches began welcoming back faithful.
item.dc:creator: Liam Stack
item.media:credit: Anna Watts for The New York Times
item.media:description: Parishioners during Thursday evening Spanish mass at Our Lady of Lourdes Church in Harlem. Many pews are blocked to create spacing due to Covid-19.

item.title: 98 Countries Pledge to Accept Afghans After US Military Departs
item.description: A joint statement from the United States and other countries said that they had “received assurances from the Taliban” that people with travel documents showing they were clear to enter any of those countries could safely depart.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Evacuees from Afghanistan arriving at Dulles International Airport in Virginia on Thursday.

item.title: Biden to Attend Return of US Service Members Killed in Kabul Airport Attack
item.description: They include 11 Marines, a Navy medic and a member of the Army.
item.dc:creator: Jim Tankersley
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: The transfer of remains at Dover Air Force Base in Delaware on Sunday.

item.title: Some Afghans say that enemies of the Taliban have begun to disappear.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: Taliban fighters in Kabul on Aug. 15, the day the militants took control of the city.

item.title: US Kills Suicide Bombers in Kabul, Official Says
item.description: The possibility of civilian casualties was being investigated. The strike came hours after President Biden had warned of another possible terrorist attack.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper, Eric Schmitt, David Zucchino, Najim Rahim and Thomas Kaplan
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Damage from what was reportedly a U.S. drone strike on a vehicle carrying explosives at a house in Kabul on Sunday.

item.title: Palestinians Finally Have Vaccines. But Will People Take Them?
item.description: For months, the Palestinian authorities struggled to get doses. Now they have the shots, but disinformation and conspiracy theories have led to widespread hesitancy.
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon
item.media:credit: Samar Hazboun for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lining up to receive vaccines in the West Bank city of Bethlehem on Thursday. The Palestinian authorities face a challenge in persuading a majority of the public to get the shots.

item.title: After Video of Abusive Nurse, Canada’s Indigenous Seek Health Overhaul
item.description: The abuse last year of an Indigenous woman in a Quebec hospital has prompted outrage and underlined the discrimination facing Canada’s Indigenous community.
item.dc:creator: Dan Bilefsky
item.media:credit: Hubert Hayaud for The New York Times

item.title: Britain, France End Their Evacuations in Afghanistan
item.description: Evacuations are slowing as U.S. officials estimate that about 350 Americans are still trying to leave Afghanistan.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Members of the British armed forces 16 Air Assault Brigade at Brize Norton, Oxfordshire, on Saturday after returning from assisting with the evacuation of people from Kabul.

item.title: All in or All Out? Biden Saw No Middle Ground in Afghanistan
item.description: President Biden’s reductionist formula has prompted a debate over whether the mayhem in Kabul was inevitable or the result of a failure to consider other options.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: A member of the U.S. Army in May aboard a helicopter over Kabul, the capital of Afghanistan.

item.title: US Reprisal Airstrike Killed Two ISIS Militants and Wounded Another
item.description: Officials refused to give details on the two killed, beyond saying that one was a planner and the other was a facilitator.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper and Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Pentagon spokesman John Kirby and Gen. William Taylor speaking at the Pentagon on Saturday.

item.title: Evacuations From Kabul Wind Down as U.S. Prepares to Pull Last Troops
item.description: Hundreds of thousands of Afghans are still thought to be seeking to flee the country, but President Biden and other global leaders have acknowledged that many will not get out before the deadline.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: Members of the Badri 313 Battalion, a group of Taliban special forces fighters, securing Kabul’s international airport and the surrounding area on Saturday.

item.title: Italy will impose tighter restrictions in Sicily after a surge in cases.
item.description: A majority of hospitalizations on the southern island have involved the unvaccinated, and many have yet to get shots.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:credit: Alberto Lo Bianco/LaPresse, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A beach in Mondello, Sicily, in May. Restrictions have been tightened in parts of Sicily, where vaccination rates are low.

item.title: Afghanistan Collapse and Strikes in Somalia Raise Snags for Drone Warfare Rules
item.description: But the Biden administration is close to finishing a new playbook for counterterrorism strikes outside conventional war zones.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:description: The Biden administration’s ability to complete the drone playbook by next month is now in doubt amid rapidly changing events and uncertainties about the future.

item.title: The U.K. is ending its civilian evacuations from Kabul today.
item.dc:creator: Aina J. Khan
item.media:description: Passengers evacuated from Afghanistan arriving at the Royal Air Force’s Brize Norton station in southern England this week.

item.title: The U.S. retaliates over the airport bombing, days before the withdrawal deadline.
item.description: The U.S. military said that it had killed its target in the first strike since a deadly attack on the Kabul airport.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Victor, Eric Schmitt, Zia ur-Rehman, Jim Huylebroek, Najim Rahim and Matthieu Aikins
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ruhullah, 16, mourned as family and friends of his father, Hussein, a victim of the suicide attack near Kabul’s airport, buried him in the hills outside the Afghan capital on Friday.

item.title: One Afghan family resettling in the U.S. finds a respite.
item.dc:creator: Miriam Jordan
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: Brishna Yousafzi, center, blowing bubbles with her brothers Huzzaif, left, and Murtaza.

item.title: A Journey Through Kabul, Afghanistan on the Day of the Fall
item.description: A Times correspondent who grew up in the Afghan capital returned before the Taliban’s victory, taking in the end of one era and the fearful start of another.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal
item.media:description: A juice vendor in downtown Kabul, Afghanistan, shortly before the city fell to the Taliban.

item.title: A Doctor’s Tour de France, One ‘Medical Desert’ at a Time
item.description: Newly graduated from medical school, Martial Jardel set off on a five-month road trip to help out in areas of France suffering from a shortage of physicians.
item.dc:creator: Gaëlle Fournier
item.media:credit: Andrea Mantovani for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dr. Martial Jardel driving his camper van near the Mont Saint-Michel, in the Normandy region of France.

item.title: How Canadian Leaders Campaign in a Pandemic
item.description: While the Conservative leader, Erin O’Toole, is still hitting the road, his party has also created a virtual method of reaching voters.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:description: Erin O’Toole, the Conservative leader, during a virtual town hall meeting this week.

item.title: Caleb Wallace, Texas Anti-Mask Rally Organizer, Sick With Covid
item.description: Caleb Wallace, a leader in the anti-mask movement in San Angelo, Texas, is in an intensive care unit and his wife says his condition is life-threatening.
item.dc:creator: Shefali S. Kulkarni

item.title: U.S. Launches Strike on ISIS-K as Bombing’s Death Toll Soars
item.description: The Pentagon said its drone strike appeared to have killed a planner for the terror group, which claimed responsibility for the blast at Kabul’s airport that left more than 170 dead.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nossiter and Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: Outside a hospital in Kabul on Friday. Hundreds were wounded in the suicide bombing at the city’s airport on Thursday.

item.title: Overlooked No More: Randy Snow, Paralympic Champion of Wheelchair Tennis
item.description: He won gold medals in singles and doubles at the 1992 Games in Barcelona and was the first Paralympic athlete to be inducted into the Olympic Hall of Fame.
item.dc:creator: Cindy Shmerler
item.media:description: Randy Snow in 1992 competing in the Paralympics in Barcelona, where he won gold medals in singles and doubles wheelchair tennis. He helped develop the sport around the world.

item.title: After Airport Bombing, an Afghan Family Buries a Father, and Hope
item.description: The former police officer, from the Hazara ethnic minority, had hoped to help his family escape the Taliban. Instead, he is now numbered among the scores killed at the Kabul airport.
item.dc:creator: Matthieu Aikins and Victor J. Blue For The New York Times
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: Women weep as they view the body of Hussain, 40, a victim of the suicide attack on HKIA Airport yesterday, at his funeral in a mosque outside of Kabul.

item.title: A U.S. Marine - a Baby on 9/11 - Is Among the Dead in Kabul
item.description: Rylee McCollum, barely older than the war itself, had a wife and a baby on the way. He was one of the first publicly identified American victims of the suicide bombing at Kabul’s airport.
item.dc:creator: Jack Healy and Dave Philipps
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Covid Creates Higher Risk for Blood Clots Than Vaccines Do
item.description: The study adds to the growing evidence that though the coronavirus vaccines are associated with certain rare side effects, those risks are dwarfed by the risks from Covid-19.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Mueller
item.media:description: A health worker prepares a dose of the AstraZeneca vaccine.

item.title: Italian Official Resigns After Uproar Over Honoring Mussolini’s Brother
item.description: Claudio Durigon, a member of the right-wing League party and a deputy economy minister, had proposed to rename a park after Benito Mussolini’s brother.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola and Gaia Pianigiani
item.media:description: Claudio Durigon, an under secretary in the economy ministry, has resigned over his controversial proposal to rename a park after the fascist brother of the former dictator Benito Mussolini.

item.title: Fossils Seized in Police Raid Demystify a Prehistoric Flying Reptile
item.description: Among the 3,000 fossils seized at a Brazilian port in 2013 was an almost complete skeleton from the pterosaur species Tupandactylus navigans, preserved in six limestone slabs.
item.dc:creator: Vimal Patel

item.title: An Afghan Refugee Built a Robot as a Message of Hope
item.description: As Afghans flee the Taliban, the experiences of a fellow countryman, Saidullah Karimi, warn of tough times ahead, but also carry a message of hope.
item.dc:creator: Alice Greenway
item.media:credit: Loulou d'Aki for The New York Times
item.media:description: Saidullah Karimi, an orthopedic technician from Afghanistan, demonstrating how the robot Athena functions. He built it largely out of items he picked out of the trash.

item.title: Pakistan emerges as a winner. What will it do now?
item.dc:creator: Jane Perlez
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: Buying Taliban flags outside the U.S. Embassy in Kabul, Afghanistan, on Sunday.

item.title: Denmark says Covid is no longer a ‘socially critical disease.’
item.dc:creator: Kaly Soto
item.media:description: Stores reopened in Copenhagen in March, as more people became vaccinated and Covid infection rates dropped.

item.title: China’s Celebrity Culture Is Raucous. The Authorities Want to Change That.
item.description: The Communist Party has declared war on idol worship, part of a broader crackdown on what it sees as toxic celebrity culture that is poisoning the minds of the country’s youth.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson, Amy Chang Chien and Cao Li
item.media:description: Zheng Shuang performing last year in Nanjing, China. A regulator accused the actress of tax evasion and ordered broadcasters to stop showing content that she has appeared in.

item.title: Biden faces a tragedy he worked to avoid.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear

item.title: The Latest From Afghanistan
item.description: We’ll start with the bombing in Kabul — and then look at the air-quality crisis in the Western U.S.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: A victim of one of the bombings in Kabul is taken to a hospital.

item.title: India Hits a Vaccine Milestone
item.description: The country has given at least one Covid-19 vaccine shot to more than half of the eligible population.
item.dc:creator: Sameer Yasir
item.media:description: Vaccinations in Mumbai earlier this month. India is still recording more than 33,000 virus cases a day.

item.title: Baby Born on Afghan Flight Is Named Reach, After Jet's Call Sign
item.description: A U.S. military commander said the baby was one of three born to women who have boarded evacuation flights out of Afghanistan.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: A C-17 military transport plane taking off from the international airport in Kabul.
